Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Coherent Manipulation and Transfer of Quantum Information amongst Single Spin Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
The emerging area of "quantum information science" has seen rapid advances in exploiting the coherent control of single spins in defect centers in diamond and SiC, opening up a new pathway toward qubits that function at room temperature. This proposal aims to extend these remarkable developments toward the coherent manipulation and full state transfer of quantum information in heterogeneous systems built from disparate materials whose individual quantum properties are already well understood. The ultimate goal is to achieve quantum-coherent communication between physically distinct quantum systems at the single spin level and at room temperature. The PIs will combine spatio-temporally resolved single spin spectroscopies with the design and fabrication of model systems that couple single spins (such as defects in SiC) with ensemble spins in low dimensional communication channels (such as 2DEGs and nanowires). The proposed research offers advanced technical training in quantum materials and measurement and provides ideal training for future careers in academics and industry. The PIs will also enhance the diversity and excellence of undergraduate research through institutional programs and by collaboratively teaching a cross-disciplinary undergraduate course on the Practice of Science.

****Non-Technical Abstract***
Modern information technology relies on devices such as lasers, flash memory and magnetic tunnel junctions that exploit the quantum mechanical aspects of the natural world. Such device technologies still do not make use of the full technological potential of quantum mechanics, restricting their functionality to control over the amplitude of quantum mechanical waves and ignoring their phase. The emerging area of "quantum information science" seeks to redress this limitation by exploring the technological possibilities of the more non-intuitive aspects of quantum mechanics, namely quantum coherence and quantum entanglement. A key challenge for quantum information processing is the development of pragmatic scenarios that will allow the exchange of coherent quantum information between disparate parts of a system. This proposal aims to demonstrate such phenomena in heterogeneous systems built from disparate materials whose individual quantum properties are well understood. The ultimate goal is to achieve quantum-coherent communication between physically distinct quantum systems at the single spin level and at room temperature. The proposed research offers advanced technical training in quantum materials and measurement and provides ideal training for future careers in academia and in industry. The PIs will also enhance the diversity and excellence of undergraduate research through institutional programs and by collaboratively teaching a cross-disciplinary undergraduate course on the Practice of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project between the PIs at the University of Chicago and at Penn State aimed to develop and understand quantum hybrid systems that serve as templates for fundamental explorations of coherent state transfer in heterogeneous solid-state systems. We focused our efforts on quantum systems whose individual quantum properties are already well under control, exploring pathways that will eventually allow us to achieve quantum-coherent communication between physically distinct quantum systems at the single spin level and at room temperature. Our goal was to explore the fundamental nature of quantum coherence, environmental interactions, and guide the development of methods to better control, or possibly extend the lifetime of, quantum coherence in the solid state. The experiments involved the control of individual defects in semiconductors, the use of advanced optical techniques that probe quantum coherence at the single spin level, and synthesis of new families of hybrid materials. 

As a model solid state quantum system, we focused on coherent control and detection of defect spins in SiC. Using ac electric fields, we developed an optically detected magnetic resonance technique to spatially map the dynamical behavior of single spins in 6H-SiC, also enabling us to image GHz frequency electric fields. The implications of this technique are wide ranging, including the promise of addressing specific single spins even in the presence of many neighbors and for transduction between spin and other degrees of freedom. We also exploited the Stark effect due to spin-spin interactions within neutral divacancies in 4H-SiC to demonstrate high-fidelity spin readout based on AC strain-sensing protocols with unprecedented sensitivity (~ 10-7 per root Hz-N range, where N is the number of interrogated spins). Using optical excitation, we demonstrated optically pumped dynamic nuclear polarization of 29-Si nuclear spins that are strongly coupled to paramagnetic electronic spin states in SiC.  Surprisingly, we observed 99 +/- 1% degree of nuclear polarization at room temperature; this corresponds to an effective nuclear temperature of 5 microKelvin. These results lay a foundation for SiC-based quantum memories, nuclear gyroscopes, and hyperpolarized probes for magnetic resonance imaging. Entanglement is a key resource for quantum computers, quantum-communication networks, and high-precision sensors. Macroscopic spin ensembles have been historically important in the development of quantum algorithms for these prospective technologies and remain strong candidates for implementing them today. This strength derives from their long-lived quantum coherence, strong signal, and ability to couple collectively to external degrees of freedom. We demonstrated that entanglement can be realized in solid-state spin ensembles at ambient conditions, using hybrid registers comprising of electron-nuclear spin pairs that are localized at color-center defects in a commercial SiC wafer. We initialized 1000 identical registers in a 40 cubic micron volume (with ~95% fidelity) and deterministically prepared them into the maximally entangled Bell states (with 0.88 ± 0.07 fidelity). To verify entanglement, we developed a register-specific quantum-state tomography protocol. The entanglement of a macroscopic solid-state spin ensemble at ambient conditions represents an important step toward practical quantum technology. We demonstrated the design and characterization of photonic crystal cavities in SiC films incorporating ensembles of electron spins with characteristics similar to those achieved in diamond. These results indicate that defect spin quantum states in SiC thin films show promise as a scalable platform for interfacing defect qubits with photonic, optoelectronic, and opto-mechanical devices. The work was published in a series of papers in Physical Review Letters, Science Advances, and Nature Photonics. 

Three dimensional topological insulators (3D TIs) are another family of quantum materials of interest for quantum information technologies.  We used optical excitation to generate and control spin dependent states in 3D TI heterostructures. We showed that circularly polarized light in conjunction with a gate-tuned chemical potential allows full control of a directional helicity-dependent photocurrent in 3D TIs even at room temperature. These results are important for engineering quantum opto-spintronic devices that rely on optical steering of spin and charge currents in future hybrid quantum systems that integrate single spin states with topological surface states. We also used photons to demonstrated reconfigurable micron-scale optical control of both magnetization and chemical potential in ferromagnetic topological insulator thin films at low temperature. By optically modulating the coercivity of the films, we were able to write and erase arbitrary patterns in their remnant magnetization, while optical manipulation of a space charge layer in the underlying SrTiO3 substrate modulated the local chemical potential of the films. Dynamic optical control over both magnetization and chemical potential of a TI may be useful in efforts to understand and control the edge states predicted at magnetic domain walls in quantum anomalous Hall insulators. By integrating such systems with single spins in SiC and diamond in future experiments, we hope to create a novel quantum information platform that combines these techniques with single spin detection of edge states. This work on topological insulators was published in Nature Communications and PNAS.
